messageBody:
Hi John,

> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of John Smith

> Cedric, I didn't examine TestNG yet. So you maybe have
> implemented my suggestion already. I want to suggest to
> support ignoring tests. Like: 1 test failed, 10 tests
> skipped, 2 tests ignored. Sometimes you want a test to set to
> ignore because all tests need to pass.
> You can comment it, but then you might forget about it. So I
> think a test framework should provide support for ignoring tests.

Funny you should say that, because that's exactly how TestNG supports
dependent tests.

You can specify that a group B of test methods "depends on" a group A of
test methods. In this case, TestNG guarantees that

- All methods in group A will be run before any method in group B is
invoked.
- All methods in group A will have succeeded. If at least one of them
failed, then all test methods in group B will be marked as "SKIPPED" (not
run), which makes it much easier for you to figure out which test exactly
broke the chain ("cascade effect").

Here is an excerpt of my slides on this subject:

===
Dependent Methods

Certain test methods depend on the successful prior run of other test
methods.
Example: testing a web server:
One test method that launches the server (launch())
One test method that pings the server (ping())
Twenty methods that test various functionalities of the server (test1() 
test20())

Problem: server is launched but ping() fails
Scenario tricky to achieve with JUnit
Result: 1 PASSED and 21 FAILURES

===
With TestNG

@Test(groups = launch)
public void launchServer() {}

@Test(groups = init,
dependsOnGroups = { launch })
public void ping() { }

@Test(dependsOnGroups = { init })
public void test1() {  }

Outcome: 1 SUCCESS, 1 FAIL, 20 SKIPS
===

Hope it clarifies things.
